meta_data.title: Strategery Episode
meta_data.subtitle: Nehemiah 4:10-23 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. It's fast, fun, free, daily, deep-dye Bible. And right now we're working on the book of Nehemiah. If you're new, welcome. You can jump in right here, or you can always go back and start at the beginning of any season. The whole podcast is available in an easy to use format at thetmbh.com. Well, I don't know how you're doing, but I'm just tickled because today we've got a passage that is all about military history and strategy. And I think it's going to be a hoot. In the second half, or really the last third of Nehemiah chapter 4, we get some of the details about exactly how Nehemiah arranges his manpower to try to prevent an attack that could come from any number of places. This is a serious problem, and it's going to take some serious strategiary to figure out how to thwart the evil designs of Sanbalat and the enemies of the rebuilding here in Nehemiah chapter 5. So you remember, yesterday we were reading about how Sanbalat and Tobiah and all these other people they got whipped into a frenzy. They're sneaking in there, they're giving threats through second-hand sources, and everybody's hearing rumblings of all of these threats about, we're going to infiltrate your ranks. When you're at least expected, boom, you're just going to get shanked and the ribs are going to kill you while you're building your wall. And the laborers, mostly just normal people who are rebuilding things, they're starting to lose heart, they've made good progress, but they're getting discouraged because the threat of being killed on zero seconds notice can cause a person to get a little distracted, get a little discouraged, understandable. And there's still a lot of work to do because there's a huge giant pile of rocks and the Nehemiah comes along and he gives an inspiring speech. Don't be afraid of them. Remember, the Lord who is great and awesome and fight for your brothers, your sons, and your daughters, your wives, and your homes. That's a pretty good speech. I mean, that's the kind of thing that you can get people fired up and ready to go. But if you're fired up and you're ready to go, but you have a horrible plan, you're still going to get absolutely annihilated if it comes to pitched physical combat. So what is the actual plan? Nehemiah 4, verse 15, when our enemies heard that we were aware of their plot and that God had frustrated it, we all returned to the wall, each to do his own work. So apparently somewhere in here, there was some threat of a full blown attack and somehow the diagnosis was the cure, just Nehemiah and the Jews being aware and getting wind of it and not crumbling, but rallying and continuing the work. That was apparently enough to thwart the initial plan of Sanbalat for how he wanted to attack, but the threat of a gorilla attack or some newly designed attack under the cover of darkness still lingers and Nehemiah is taking that very seriously, verse 16. From that day on, half my men did the work while the other half were equipped with spears, shields, bows and armor. The officers posted themselves behind all the people of Judah. Okay. Well, there's one thing that jumps off of the page for me right there that I hadn't caught until right this second. And that is the spears, shields, bows and armor. He didn't say armor before, did he? Maybe you know, where is that? Because we had swords and spears and bows for sure. Oh, it's right here, verse 13. Therefore, I stationed some of the people behind the lowest points of the wall at the exposed places, posting them by families with their swords, spears and bows. No armor. Okay. Well, let's think about that. Is it significant that armor is added to the list? You know what? I think it is significant. Armor is super heavy. What would this armor have been like? Um, okay. Probably one of two things. The Persians during the generation of Darius and Xerxes, their elite units tended to use almost what looks like a wicker armor, like from Pier 1 imports, if you remember that store, literally woven heavy stick work that they would create armor plates out of. It would almost look like a hybrid of a Western armor, but almost like a samurai armor or something. You'd picture being an Eastern armor as well. And you wouldn't think that would work. But one time in college, I had this great professor who was always doing military tactics, simulations with us as part of the history degree coursework. And he was trying to explain how this wicker armor would work and why it was effective. And so he brought in some wicker, like, uh, from a lawn chair or something. It wasn't that impressive. It certainly wasn't armor. He demonstrated how it was very effective at deflecting a blow or two, even a projectile. And especially if it were treated or even thicker and designed to obstruct that, it worked really well against the weapons of war in the fifth century BC. Now, okay, in fairness, that armor didn't work out so well in the campaign against the Greeks because the Persians lost, but it wasn't the armor's fault when Xerxes went lost to the Athenians and Themistocles, uh, generation earlier than what we're looking at here in Nehemiah. I mean, it was bad command decisions fault and their ultimate defeat was really a naval battle. In the armor, it would make sense that Nehemiah and his retinue would have traveled in that Persian wicker style armor that the immortals were known to wear as an elite fighting unit dedicated to the king and the people who were immediately in proximity to the king. It's also possible that they were wearing more of a 11 teen ancient near Eastern armor that let me see it this time. It would have been bronze, maybe iron, and that would have been heavier and clunkier. It wouldn't have covered the whole body. Don't think night in shining armor. Think more like covering a few vitals, maybe the shoulders, but I don't know. I would think that the armor of the day would have been that Persian style armor. Okay. Whatever the case, it's unwieldy. It's heavy. And as soon as you go from there are people with bows and spears and swords up to bows and spears and swords and armor. Okay. What you've done then effectively at that point is you've made it impossible for those people to just set down their weapon, pick up a trowel, knock out a little bit of stone work, and then quick pick up a spear again. If somebody gets too close that looks dangerous. Now, at this point, you have created a professional army, a full time division of the total manpower you have to work with. And you've created a workforce division. You can tell them apart because one's wearing armor and one is not. Nehemiah's got a strategic conundrum here because he's trying to cover a whole lot of wall, but he doesn't have a whole lot of people to do it. I don't know that we ever figured out exactly what the dimensions were on this thing. Let me thumb back this direction a little bit. There's a cool diagram. All right. This is making it look like it might have been about two miles, 11,000 feet of wall total. So they got to cover that. Well, how many dudes does it take to cover two miles worth of line and not let people through? Think about this. If Sanbalat and his ilk break through at any weak point, they're now in the back field going at the back side of all of the workers. The soldiers are on the wrong side of the fight now. Basically, Sanbalat at that point would be in your base killing your dudes. It's a serious, serious problem because where do you put your guys to defend all of that range? Well, obviously you go to the parts of the wall that are weakest and most vulnerable. But even then, Sanbalat has a strategic advantage here because he can move all of his troops around, especially under cover of darkness. And if he can do that without the defenders seeing where he's attacking from and he can get into that attack quickly as a chance to break through, get inside the walls and then everything's over there. It's going to be a complete and total route. But on the other hand, Nehemiah has the advantage because if they can detect where Sanbalat's attack is coming from, then they can quickly rally a bunch of troops from places that don't need to be guarded at the moment. They can cover that breach and hold him off. Internal movement in a defensive line is easier than external movement. That's why when you look at battle maps, the defensive formation will always be concave. That is, there'll be a little bit of room in between the two ends of the defensive line. It'll be kind of curved even like a horseshoe a little bit because it's really fast to go from one end of the defensive line to anywhere else in the defensive line when the thing is a half circle. It's easier than if it's two miles spread all the way out. But you got to have a system to let people know so that you can quickly move troops inside the walls to hold off any potential attack. And it would be weird to me if there was no account of what the plan was for that in Nehemiah, but there is an account of what the plan was for that right here where it says, the officers posted themselves, man, all the people of Judah who were building the wall, those who carried materials did their work with one hand and held a weapon in the other. That is not convenient. And each of the builders wore his sword at his side as he worked. So you could rally anybody. Anybody could drop the trowel and go to the sword. Obviously your armored tanks are going to be more effective, but anybody could fight and move interior to the walls. But how are they going to know that question? Still lingers. Here we go. Verse 18, but the man who sounded the trumpet stayed with me brilliant. So we got a beacon system. We got a warning alarm system. Nehemiah's job is basically to patrol around, know where all of the vulnerable spots are. No doubt had an alert system and sentries stationed about so that through a series of blasts on the trumpet, remember, this is a two mile range. That is big. But through a series of blasts on the trumpet, people could quickly rally and reorganize to a vulnerable spot. Now, Sam Belat's going to figure this out. I mean, there's no hiding it. He's going to be able to see what the defensive strategy is. And he's going to be discouraged from attacking because it is a very good defensive strategy is the correct defensive strategy. This is the defensive strategy that allowed the union to barely barely barely barely hold the line at the battle of Gettysburg. They took a defensive position and just curled the edges so they could maintain lines of communication so they could reallocate troops to vulnerable positions and so that they could have faster movement behind the lines than the Confederacy could have on the wide side of the line. So this is a timeless strategy. He's making a ton of sense. Nehemiah goes on here in verse 19 talking about his strategy. Then I said to the nobles, the officials and the rest of the people, the work is extensive and spread out and we are widely separated from each other along the wall. Whenever you hear the sound of the trumpet, join us there. Our God will fight for us. So we continued the work with half the men holding spears from the first light of dawn till the stars came out. At that time, I also said to the people have every man and his helper stay inside Jerusalem at night so they can serve us as guards by night and workmen by day. Neither I nor my brothers nor my men nor the guards with me took off our clothes. Each had his weapon even when we went for water. Simply put, these guys are on all the time. You know what it is to be in a high pressure situation, even just a social situation where you can't really relax or ever let your guard down. You got to be sharp. You got to be on. It's exhausting. And these guys are fixing to do this for a period of several weeks if need be. And it's not just a social threat. It's literally the threat of we could be attacked and killed at any given moment. Everybody stay ready. Everybody keep your sword within reach and somehow and here the only way out, the only way to get past to this very miserable, difficult time. The only way out is through. We got to build the wall. We got to build the wall. We got to build the wall. When the wall is done, this very difficult time ends, but we're going to have a tough time getting there and it's going to require some extraordinary measures and some extraordinary sacrifices and some extraordinary endurance on the part of everybody from Nehemiah at the top all the way down to the perfume maker's daughter who is helping with her little segment of the wall. This is an all in effort and it's very demanding and it's very tiresome. But this is what it takes to beat an enemy when you really aren't in a great defensive position. You've got a ton of vulnerabilities and the clock is ticking. I keep telling you, I'm a big fan of Nehemiah because I'm a big fan of Nehemiah. I like his leadership. He does things that make sense. He's practically minded, but he also understands that the people he's working with are people. They're humans and he's like a dad to them, a grandfather to them. He's always nurturing them and encouraging them. He's cognizant of what it would be like to be them. He's a good leader and I'm having fun looking at this and trying to think about how I can take cues from how he does it as we chew through this thing together. All right. That's plenty for today. I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. Let's do this again soon.
